ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: When alt was accidentally omitted, the UA can predict there's a good chance it's a decorative image (based on statistics from current content). When an image is explicitly marked as being critical content, there should be a much better chance that it actually is critical content. That can set the initial bias for any heuristics when the UA is trying to decide how to present the image to the user

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:02): (The heuristics might be as simple as "if it's got no alt, it's probably decorative, so ignore it" and "if it's marked as important, say "image, press enter for more information"")

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:05): but they don't all have names like spacer.gif

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:07): so that can be one of the heuristics the spec talks about
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (03:08): I'd imagine some people use spacers that are the same color as the background, too?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:08): my point is that i don't see that lack of alt text is any more of a legacy problem we face than is bad alt text

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:13): They're both problems, but it seems easier to solve the first problem (by identifying intentionally-omitted-alt with some new syntax, so authors can make sure their critical images don't get ignored by incorrect heuristics) than the second problem, and partially solving one problem is usually better than solving none (except when solving that problem takes far too much effort to be worthwhile and distracts from other problems :-) )
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:18): it's not clear to me that it is possible to identify intentionally-omitted-alt from lazily-omitted-alt.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:19): (or from ignorantly-included-alt)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:20): because tools tend to mix all three of those up

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:31): It's not possible to identify them if the syntax for both is <img src=...> with no alt, so it'd need other syntax like <img noalt> or <figure><img></figure> or whatever
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:31): i don't understand why the syntax makes things any better

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:31): Then they'd still get mixed up and used wrong, but there should be some (imperfect) correlation between images-marked-as-important (with intentionally omitted alt) and images-which-are-important, so UAs can make more accurate guesses - they still have to guess, but they can guess better than with no extra information, and good authors can help their users by making UAs guess in the right direction
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:31): what will stop people from using <img noalt> to shut up the validator?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:32): i guess i'm not convinced that it would really improve matters that much
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (03:33): I suspect the primary use of @noalt would be to make the validator stop complaining

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:34): in particular, i'm not convinced that if we added an <img noalt> or <img missing-alt> attribute, that well-meaning people would be able to tell the difference between <img alt=""> and <img missing-alt> or <img noalt>.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:34): and we would actually end up making it worse -- making images that are critical get explicitly marked as decorative (<img alt="">)
